translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty🔽The twentieth chapter
The discussion of knowledge
“Is there no knowledge in the ordinary person?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Natthi puthujjanassa paññā pajānanā vicayo pavicayo dhammavicayo sallakkhaṇā upalakkhaṇā paccupalakkhaṇāti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…🔽nanu atthi puthujjanassa paññā pajānanā vicayo …pe…
analyzed: āmantā  natthi puthujjanassa paññā pajānanā vicayaḥ pavicayaḥ dhamma vicayo sallakkhaṇā upalakkhaṇā paccupalakkhaṇā ati  na ha ivam vattabbe pe  nanu atthi puthujjanassa paññā pajānanā vicayo pe
translated: “Yes.”

“Is there no understanding, no discernment, no investigation, no searching, no comprehensive discernment, no discernment of right and wrong, no higher understanding, no knowledge in the ordinary person?”
The Invitation Ceremony.

original: Hañci atthi puthujjanassa paññā pajānanā vicayo …pe…🔽paccupalakkhaṇā, no ca vata re vattabbe—🔽“natthi puthujjanassa ñāṇan”ti.
analyzed: hañci atthi puthujjanassa paññā pajānanā vicayaḥ pe  paccupalakkhaṇā no ca vata re vattabbe  natthi puthujjanassa ñāṇan ti
translated: “Then it is not right to say that there is no knowledge in the ordinary person.”
“Is there no knowledge in the ordinary person?”
“Yes.”
“Can the ordinary person attain the first jhana?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci puthujjano paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ samāpajjeyya, no ca vata re vattabbe—🔽“natthi puthujjanassa ñāṇan”ti.
analyzed: āmantā  hañci puthujjanaḥ paṭhamam jhānam samāpajjeyya no ca vata re vattabbe  natthi puthujjanassa ñāṇan ti
translated: “Yes.”

analyzed: puthujjanaḥ dutiyam jhānam pe  tatiyam jhānam
translated: “Then it is not right to say that there is no knowledge in the ordinary person.”🔽“Can the ordinary person attain the second jhana …🔽the third jhana …
the fourth jhana …

analyzed: ākāsānaccāyatanam samāpajjeyya  viññāṇañcāyatanam ākiñcaññāyatanam nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samāpajjeyya
translated: “He could attain the dimension of the infinitude of space,🔽the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, the dimension of nothingness, and the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

analyzed: puthujjanaḥ dānam dadeyya pe  cīvaram dadeyya  piṇḍapātam dadeyya
translated: “Could a person of the world give a gift of a robe,🔽give a gift of almsfood,
give a gift of a dwelling,

analyzed: gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāram dadeyya ati
translated: give a gift of medicine and supplies for the sick?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci puthujjano gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṁ dadeyya, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci puthujjanaḥ gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāram dadeyya no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Yes.”
“Well then, it is not right to say that a person of the world has no knowledge.”
“Does a person of the world have knowledge?”
“Yes.”

original: Puthujjano tena ñāṇena dukkhaṁ parijānāti, samudayaṁ pajahati, nirodhaṁ sacchikaroti, maggaṁ bhāvetīti?
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ tena ñāṇena dukkham parijānāti samudayam pajahati nirodham sacchikaroti maggam bhāveti iti
translated: “Does a person of the world, by means of that knowledge, understand suffering, abandon the origination of suffering, realize the cessation of suffering, and develop the path?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
The Discussion of Knowledge is finished.
